newsitem.title: USA: S. Calif. companies set to increase hiring -survey.
newsitem.headline: S. Calif. companies set to increase hiring -survey.

text.p: Southern California companies plan to increase office personnel in the first half of 1997 in a sign of continued economic growth in the state, according to a report released on Monday.

Twenty-three percent of southern California companies anticipated an increase in hiring full-time staff in the first half of 1997, while only five percent expected a decrease, according to a survey by Irvine-based Thomas Staffing Services Inc, a unit of Personnel Group of America Inc, a staffing services company.

"This data suggests companies are anticipating a sustained economic recovery, as opposed to the early '90s where economic trends were uncertain," Gene Wilson, president of Thomas Staffing, said in a statement.

Interviews with human resource executives at 951 randomly selected companies in the counties of Los Angeles, Orange, San Diego, Riverside, San Bernardino and Kern were conducted during the fourth quarter of 1996, Thomas Staffing said.
